ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT THE STATIONARY SOURCE
PLM Operations, LLC dba Paleteria La Michoacana (PLM), Modesto, California Facility (Facility) is located at 2068 Lapham Drive, Modesto, California, approximately 50 yards south of State Highway 132 (Yosemite Boulevard) and is approximately 300 yards west of Mitchell Road. The Facility produces and stores ice cream products. Anhydrous ammonia is used in the refrigeration systems at the Facility. PLM has developed a California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program in general accordance with the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4, and Federal EPA requirements, 40 CFR Part 68 Risk Management Plan (RMP), and federal OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) 29 CFR 1910.119 and California OSHA 8 CCR 5189 to enhance already existing anhydrous ammonia safety and emergency action programs. PLM Operations, LLC was purchased by Tropicale Foods, LLC in 2018. The management team is committed to worker and public safety through investment in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration systems. PLMs policy is to implement reasonable controls to reduce foreseeable releases of regulated substances. PLM relies on support services provided by the local fire department and the Stanislaus County Hazardous Materials Response team in the unlikely event that a chemical release does occur at the Facility.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED 
PLM has two anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems at the Facility: the Versaline System and the Plant System. The two systems are defined as one process due to an interconnection at the purger which is opened periodically during normal operation. An ammonia leak detection system and an ammonia diffusion tank are ancillary systems that support the process.

The Versaline system utilizes approximatel

y 1,500 pounds of the 12,600-pound ammonia process inventory to operate a brine cooling system. The Versaline System is composed of the following key components:
 1 Condenser
 1 Control Pressure Receiver
 1 Oil pot
 1 FES compressor 
 1 Chiller evaporator with an accumulator vessel
 1 Liquid transfer vessel (LTV)

The Versaline System operation cycle begins at the control-pressure receiver where liquid ammonia is fed to the chiller evaporator. At this point, the ammonia flashes down to saturation temperature, then is pumped from the chiller evaporator where it absorbs heat from the brine. Vapor is returned to the compressor and compressed and the pressure is increased to condensing pressure. The superheated compressor discharge travels through the evaporative condenser where the ammonia gas gives up its heat and is condensed to a liquid and returned to the control-pressure receiver to begin the cycle once again.
 
The Plant System has two different operating pressures and temperatures with an estimated inventory of approximately 11,100 pounds. One operating pressure has a corresponding temperature of 20 degrees F and is referred to as the medium temperature. The medium temperature equipment serves both air handlers on the roof and the 34-degree cold box. The second operating pressure has a corresponding temperature of -50 degrees F and serves the two -15-degree freezers for product storage, four ice cream freezers, and one spiral quick freeze tunnel. The Plant System is composed of the following key components:
 1- Condenser, BAC model VC2-887
 1- High pressure receiver, 60 x 12
 1- Oil pot, 8.625 x 36
 1- 600 HP compressor (low temp), model N250-VMD-Y
 1 250 HP FES retrofit, serial number 95118101, 2/27/94 (glycol system)
 4- Cherry Burrell ice cream freezers
 1- Air handler Versaline room (north), Accuair model #AA-20-99
 1- Air handler Vitaline room (south), Accuair model #AA-05-95
 1- Diffusion tank, 10 x 20, 10,184 Gallons
 1- Low temp screw compressor p

ackage (LTC-2), Mycom 250-VMDD 600 hp
 1- Spiral freezer with 4 evaporator coils
 1- Medium temp recirculator, 42 x 10
 1  Oil pot
 1- Low temp recirculator, Morfab model #MRP-54V, 54 x 12
 1- Evaporator coil (34-degree cold box), EV-8, Krack
 2- Ammonia pumps (low temp), Teikoku #R42-316F4AM-0506TI-E
 1- Ammonia pump (medium temp), Cornell pump with Baldor motor #A15087G-55

The Plant System operating cycle begins with the high-pressure receiver where the liquid is fed into the medium temperature recirculator. At this point, the ammonia flashes down to saturation temperature, then is pumped to the low temperature recirculator, and the 34 degrees cold box evaporator coil, two air handlers on the roof, and four Cherry Burrell ice cream freezers where it absorbs heat. Vapor is returned to the compressor where it is compressed, and the pressure is increased to condensing pressure. The superheated compressor discharge travels through the evaporative condenser where the ammonia gas gives up its heat and is condensed to a liquid and returned to the high-pressure receiver to begin the cycle once again.

Liquid ammonia from the medium-temperature recirculator is fed into the low-temperature recirculator by a solenoid valve controlled by a level controller. Within the low-temperature recirculator, the ammonia flashes down to a colder saturation temperature, then is pumped to the spiral freezer, and the two  15-degree storage freezers where it absorbs heat. Vapor is returned to the compressor where it is compressed, and the pressure is increased to condensing pressure. The superheated compressor discharge travels through the evaporative condenser where the ammonia gas gives up its heat and is condensed to a liquid and returned to the high-pressure receiver to begin the cycle once again.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL -SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The CalARP and federal RMP regulations require facilities to assess chemical release scenarios resul

ting from potential failures of the chemical handling systems. Facilities are required to perform a hazard assessment and offsite consequence analysis which includes a worst-case release scenario (release parameters are defined by the regulations) and an alternative release scenario. The regulations define a worst-case release scenario as the greatest amount held in a single vesselreleased as a gas over 10 minutes. An alternative release scenario is identified as a release that is more likely to occur at the Facility. These are not summarized herein as recommended by EPA but are presented in the CalARP/RMP Program.
PLM has implemented prevention program elements to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia for refrigeration. In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized verify safe practices are being performed. The CalARP/RMP/PSM Prevention Program elements include the following:
 Process Safety Information
 Process Hazard Analysis
 Operating Procedures
 Training Programs
 Mechanical Integrity
 Management of Change
 Pre-startup Safety Review
 Compliance Audits
 Incident Investigation
 Employee Participation
 Hot Work Permits
 Contractor Safety
 Trade Secrets (if applicable)

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no releases of ammonia meeting the reporting requirements at the PLM Facility in the past 5 years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
PLM will not respond to uncontrolled releases of ammonia from the process and will rely on support services provided by the local fire department and the Stanislaus County Hazardous Materials Response team in the unlikely event that a chemical release occurs at the Facility. PLM has written and implemented an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the Facility. The plans initial actions are to evacuate the Facility to designated assembly areas and wait for instructions from outside emergency response agencies. The EAP is periodically reviewed by PLM management and is coordin

ated annually with emergency response agencies.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
PLM performed an update and revalidation of the 2017 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) in November 2022. The PHA team prepared a list of suggested safety improvements and mitigation measures. PHA team recommendations included:
	Evaluate access to valves and the need for installing chainwheels.
	Conduct weekly inspection of the eyewash shower units.
	Use a spotter when operating a forklift near ammonia refrigeration equipment.
	Evaluate the need for roof access on the west side of the building.
PLM will respond to suggested mitigation measures promptly and has established completion schedules for proposed actions in accordance with the 2 ½-year time frame set forth in the January 1, 2015, CalARP program or as negotiated with a representative of Stanislaus County Department of Environmental Resources (SCDER).

PLM recognizes that the CalARP/RMP/PSM Program is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring, and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operations at its Facility. As such, this document and related attachments and program elements will evolve as PLM continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for their employees and surrounding community. PLM will submit revised information if a change occurs that is considered significant and requires resubmission under the regulations. However, minor improvements/modifications to the CalARP/RMP/PSM Programs, related attachments, and program elements will be incorporated consistent with PLMs internal review practices, and PLM will maintain the most current versions onsite. Thus, the most current version of the CalARP/RMP/PSM Programs and related documents and elements maintained onsite may vary slightly from the information in submittals made to regulatory agencies.
